title: R43984
content: Songwriters and recording artists are entitled to payment for reproductions and performances of their music. However, they do not have total control over their music. For example, Taylor Swift can withdraw her own recorded music from Spotify as a singer who owns the rights to her sound recordings, but she cannot dictate how the service uses other recorded versions of her musical works. Ms. Swift can withdraw her recorded music from Spotify, but cannot control how the service uses other versions of her works. Payment for her music depends on market forces, contracts, and copyright laws. Congress updated laws in the 1990s to address digital music distribution, balancing copyright protection and industry revenue. The evolution of music distribution has blurred traditional lines of exploitation, with streaming services changing the industry landscape. In 1999, recording industry revenues peaked at $21.3 billion, coinciding with the introduction of Napster. Apple's iTunes Music Store launched in 2003, offering legal online song purchases. By 2012, digital downloads surpassed physical media sales in the recording industry. In 2012, digital music downloads surpassed physical media sales in the recording industry, with Apple holding a 65% market share. However, sales declined as streaming services like Spotify gained popularity. To compete, Apple launched Apple Music in 2015. Subscription music services have since dominated music consumption, with digital subscriptions and streaming services accounting for 67% of total U.S. recording industry retail spending in 2017. Consumer spending on music has shifted towards webcasting, satellite digital audio radio services, cable services, and streaming music services, increasing from 9% in 2011 to 67% in 2017. Despite flat spending between 2014 and 2015, there was a 10% growth between 2015 and 2016, and a 14% growth between 2016 and 2017. However, annual spending on music by U.S. consumers, adjusted for inflation, remains significantly below its 1999 peak.
